subject: HowStuffWorks Computers & Electronics Newsletter July 5, 2007
body:
July 5, 2007 
RSS | 
computers & electronicsThis Week's Highlights:
How Computer Keyboards WorkHow to Buy a Laptop
How Inkjet Printers WorkHow Motes Work
How Google Earth Works 
This Month in History - July - Just about everyone in the United 
States has heard of the little town known as Roswell, N.M. Most people know that there is some connection 
between Roswell
and UFOs. But not many people know the real details. Read more about
this and other major events that happened in the month of July.    This week's trivia question:How many keys are on a computer keyboard? 
Find out
   
How Computer Keyboards Work
- With all the extras and options that are available for new computer
keyboards, it's hard to believe that their original design came from
mechanical typewriters that didn't even use electricity. Learn about
keyboard technology.     This week's video:
How to Buy a Laptop - Laptops are now almost as popular as desktop computers. This video
 from HowStuffWorks will show you the key factors to consider when buying a laptop.  
    Also at HowStuffWorks:
 How Inkjet Printers Work
 - An inkjet printer is any printer that places extremely small droplets of ink onto paper to create an image.  Learn about the various parts of an inkjet printer and how these parts work together to create an image.  
 How Motes Work
 - Smart dust sounds like something out of a Disney movie, but it's not. Also called a mote or a wireless sensing network, this new technology is intriguing everyone from military personnel to vineyard owners. Find out what the big deal is and explore the many possible applications of this tiny device. 
 How Google Earth Works 
- Online mapping programs are great for those of us who get lost easily, and they're just plain fun. Google Earth is available for download as a desktop application, although you need to be connected to the Internet to use it.  Learn why Google Earth is no ordinary mapping application.   
   
Coming Soon: How the iPhone WorksHow Virtual Reality Works
